queue.targetText: A year ago, a child I know came out as trans to me. Last month, they told me they were non-binary. No one has ever made me prouder than them for their bravery and emotional intelligence. Children know their own internal worlds and they know when something feels off. #transrights
queue.context: Genuine observation about emotional intelligence and self-knowledge in children - touches our themes authentically

queue.targetText:
For many women, Menopause is a doorway to clearer boundaries, deeper self-knowledge, and a more authentic life. But these gifts can‚Äôt be accessed in silence.

It's time to speak openly about menopause. Wisdom shouldn‚Äôt be ignored.

Read more in Kingstonist Feb 16.

queue.context: Menopause as threshold to deeper self-knowledge and authenticity - good example of tension-as-doorway, breaking silence

queue.targetText:
I always love when I say something and I get the reply:

‚ÄúProve it. Show evidence!!‚Äù

And I say: ‚Äúlook it up your self‚Äù

Them: ‚Äúsee you can‚Äôt prove it!‚Äù

No

I can. 

The issue here is the demand for ala carte knowledge easily discoverable by simply a cursory exploration. 

Them: ‚Äúshow me proof or y
queue.context: Touches on intellectual laziness vs genuine curiosity - relevant to growth/knowledge themes.
Clean observation about the distinction between mental and emotional intelligence - our territory.

completed.targetText:
The idea:

1) once you know a fact, you can't simply un-know it ("the curse of knowledge") 
2) so, to effectively pretend not to know something, you need to rely on your self-model to simulate a state of ignorance ("how would I have behaved if I didn't know?")
completed.context: Sophisticated exploration of self-knowledge paradox: using self-model to simulate ignorance. Original thought that perfectly captures our tension/self-knowledge themes
